item.title: [ENTESB-4495] Hibernate and Bundle ClassLoaders out of sync on Bundle Refresh
item.description:
Using Fuse 6.1 which ships Hibernate 4.2.9.Final, there is an issue with certain bundle refreshes and deployments that manifests in 2 ways.

CCE on finds

Caused by: java.lang.ClassCastException: org.mrobson.example.minihibernate.datamodel.Person cannot be cast to org.mrobson.example.minihibernate.datamodel.Person

PropertyAccessException on merges

Cause: org.hibernate.PropertyAccessException: could not get a field value by reflection getter of org.mrobson.example.minihibernate.datamodel.Person.id Error: IllegalArgumentException: Can not set int field org.mrobson.example.minihibernate.datamodel.Person.id to org.mrobson.example.minihibernate.datamodel.Person

Attached are 3 screenshots from the heapdump.

person_bundleCL_osgiCL_CCE.png shows the Person class from BundleClassLoader 0xe1ce0250 mapped to the Hibernate OsgiClassLoader.

Drilling down on the OsgiClassLoader, it's referencing the old BundleClassLoader which has an out of date reference to a Person class object that no longer maps to the datamodel bundles ClassLoader.

person_bundleREV_bundleCL_CCE.png shows my datamodel bundle with it's Person class in BundleClassLoader 0xe22d9420 thus putting the parent and sub enhanced class within different classloaders as well as being incorrectly mapped to the OsgiClassLoader.

person_bundleREV_buncleCL_Working.png shows restarting again to bring things into a working state.

OsgiClassLoader references BundleClassLoader 0xf7c89828 which maps to both Person from datamodel and the enhanced Person class.

It looks like in this case Hibernate is not re-creating the OSGI classloader mappings with updated references when certain combinations of bundle restarts or deployments happen with the bundle containing the entity classes. From there, it's references end up out of date.

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Looking at the hibernate osgi code, it seems a single OsgiClassLoader instance is created.
That's wrong, as it will held references to staled bundles.

Each OsgiSessionFactoryService#getService method call should create a new OsgiClassLoader whenever a service is requested for a given bundle.

Guillaume Nodet Looks like Hibernate has somewhat taken this approach with the 5.x release [1]. I guess we need to see if anything can be done about it now in 4.2.x.

Through the commit for that change, I found [2] which seems like it's still a work in progress, targeting 5.1...

[1] https://github.com/hibernate/hibernate-orm/blob/5.0/hibernate-osgi/src/main/java/org/hibernate/osgi/OsgiSessionFactoryService.java#L68
[2] https://hibernate.atlassian.net/browse/HHH-9818

I've checked if we can simply nullify org.hibernate.internal.util.ClassLoaderHelper#overridenClassLoader and set correct TCCL, but looks like we can't do it.
When you refresh datamodel bundle, org.mrobson.example.hibernatetx.datamodel.Person classes are loaded from new bundle class loader, but inside hibernate, these classes are instantiated using org.hibernate.tuple.PojoInstantiator#constructor field. I've checked the dependency/reference path and we have:

org.hibernate.tuple.PojoInstantiator ← org.hibernate.tuple.entity.PojoEntityTuplizer ← org.hibernate.persister.entity.SingleTableEntityPersister ← org.hibernate.internal.SessionFactoryImpl#entityPersisters

so we have references to stale classes (via "constructor" object) from session factory. And without osgi:refreshing it, we're doomed...

OK, I've checked Guillaume's changes. There are two things needed:

1. Change in Aries:

diff --git a/jpa/jpa-container/src/main/java/org/apache/aries/jpa/container/unit/impl/PersistenceUnitInfoImpl.java b/jpa/jpa-container/src/main/java/org/apache/aries/jpa/container/unit/impl/PersistenceUnitInfoImpl.java
 
index 11341b3..b295f61 100644
 
--- a/jpa/jpa-container/src/main/java/org/apache/aries/jpa/container/unit/impl/PersistenceUnitInfoImpl.java
 
+++ b/jpa/jpa-container/src/main/java/org/apache/aries/jpa/container/unit/impl/PersistenceUnitInfoImpl.java
 
@@ -100,12 +100,7 @@ public class PersistenceUnitInfoImpl implements PersistenceUnitInfo {
 
   }
 
 
   public ClassLoader getClassLoader() {
 
-    if (cl.get() == null) {
 
-        // use forced because for even for a resolved bundle we could otherwise get null
 
-        cl.compareAndSet(null, AriesFrameworkUtil.getClassLoaderForced(bundle));
 
-    }
 
-    
-    return cl.get();
 
+    return AriesFrameworkUtil.getClassLoaderForced(bundle);
 
   }
 
 
   @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")

2. Change in Hibernate (Fuse 6.1 uses currently Hibernate 4.2.9.Final, Fuse 6.2: Hibernate 4.2.20.Final-redhat-1): https://github.com/gnodet/hibernate-orm/commit/a22c4d9b5898cab42c92253d28fabb3f49790dd7

With Aries and Fuse 6.1 it's easy - the fix is already here. There's also fix for ENTESB-4429.
With Fuse 6.2, we have to wait for community release. Guillaume Nodet, can you take care of it?

Matthew Robson, I've checked this issue (and ENTESB-4447) using attached:

  • org.apache.aries.jpa.container-1.0.1.redhat-611453.jar
  • hibernate-osgi-4.2.9.Final.jar

and it works - I was using Fuse 6.1.1.redhat-453. Could you please check it too?

There are 2 commits to fix this in Hibernate 4.2 branch:
1) https://github.com/hibernate/hibernate-orm/commit/d1e93c4a1bdb26a80c9490c2256e625a5810a7ca
2) https://github.com/hibernate/hibernate-orm/commit/49e62304da028d81b27ffdcaf35f93876906f8dd

1) is linked to this Jira because the commit message contains "ENTESB-4495"; 2) is not attached because, unfortunately, "ENTESB-4495" was left out of the commit message.

Thanks Susan Javurek I tried to test the update command on data model bundle and it throws this exception:

Caused by: org.hibernate.service.UnknownServiceException: Unknown service requested [org.hibernate.service.jdbc.connections.spi.ConnectionProvider]
 
	at org.hibernate.service.internal.AbstractServiceRegistryImpl.getService(AbstractServiceRegistryImpl.java:151)

Which looks like that bundle CXF Hibernate needs to rewire packages after the update of Datamodel bundle. It can be done by osgi:update on CXF Hibernate bundle or using osgi:refresh on Datamodel.

For me it works like this:

JBossFuse:karaf@root> list -t 0 -l|grep robson
 
[ 321] [Active     ] [Created     ] [       ] [   80] mvn:org.mrobson.example.hibernatetx/xa-datasource/1.0-SNAPSHOT
 
[ 322] [Active     ] [Created     ] [       ] [   80] mvn:org.mrobson.example.hibernatetx/datamodel/1.0-SNAPSHOT
 
[ 323] [Active     ] [Created     ] [       ] [   80] mvn:org.mrobson.example.hibernatetx/cxfhibernate/1.0-SNAPSHOT
 
JBossFuse:karaf@root> update 322
 
JBossFuse:karaf@root> refresh 322
 
JBossFuse:karaf@root>

When I removed <property name="hibernate.hbm2ddl.auto" value="create-drop" /> I could correctly see records being preserved and http://localhost:8181/cxf/hibernatetx/person/findById/1 always returned correct result without problems after update 322 + refresh 322.

no need to refresh hibernate itself, but you have to refresh your updated bundle - refresh is needed to rewire hibernate to new version of your bundle. That's how OSGi works.

Also, to prove that hibernate works fine, I debugged the refresh operation.
At:

"FelixFrameworkWiring@11543" daemon prio=5 tid=0x97 nid=NA runnable
 
  java.lang.Thread.State: RUNNABLE
 
	  at org.apache.felix.framework.Felix.refreshPackages(Felix.java:4084)
 
	  at org.apache.felix.framework.FrameworkWiringImpl.run(FrameworkWiringImpl.java:178)
 
	  at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)

we have this code:

// Create map of bundles that import the packages
 
// from the target bundles.
 
bundles = new HashSet<Bundle>();
 
for (Bundle target : newTargets)
 
{
 
    // If anyone passes in a null bundle, then just
 
    // ignore it.
 
    if (target != null)
 
    {
 
        // Add the current target bundle to the map of
 
        // bundles to be refreshed.
 
        bundles.add(target);
 
        // Add all importing bundles to map.
 
        populateDependentGraph((BundleImpl) target, bundles);
 
    }
 
}

when refreshing bundle by ID, Felix first collects a closure of bundles that import packages from bundle that's being refreshed.
When I refreshed datamodel bundle I saw only these bundles in the closure. Each such bundle will be: stopped, rewired, started:

newTargets: java.util.Collection  = {java.util.Arrays$ArrayList@11955}  size = 1
 
 0 = {org.apache.felix.framework.BundleImpl@11718} "org.mrobson.example.hibernatetx.datamodel [322]"
 
bundles: java.util.Set  = {java.util.HashSet@12062}  size = 2
 
 0 = {org.apache.felix.framework.BundleImpl@12067} "org.mrobson.example.hibernatetx.cxfhibernate [323]"
 
 1 = {org.apache.felix.framework.BundleImpl@11718} "org.mrobson.example.hibernatetx.datamodel [322]"

As you can see, hibernate-osgi bundle don't have to be refreshed. Only cxfhibernate bundle does - to use latest hibernate's entitymanager that's related to updated datamodel bundle.

Everything works as expected.

<ggrzybek> AH! the most important thing is that I removed both org.mrobson.example.hibernatetx.activator.Activator#start() and org.mrobson.example.hibernatetx.activator.Activator#start()
 
<ggrzybek> they are not necessary

According to the OSGi specification, it is not enough to "update" bundles depending on a previous revision to switch to the new revision. You also need to refresh. When you update the data model bundle, you'll need to immediately refresh it which will avoid the problem, i.e:

JBossFuse:karaf@root> list |grep -i datamodel
 
[ 297] [Active     ] [Created     ] [       ] [   95] hibernatetx :: Datamodel (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)
 
 
 
JBossFuse:karaf@root> update 297

Hibernate: create table addresses (id integer not null auto_increment, addedBy varchar(80) not null, addedOn datetime not null, lastChangedBy varchar(80) not null, lastChangedDate datetime not null, version bigint not null, city varchar(255) not null, person_id integer not null, primary key (id))

    • Note the error occurs at this point, then refresh:

JBossFuse:karaf@root> refresh 297

Hibernate: create table addresses (id integer not null auto_increment, addedBy varchar(80) not null, addedOn datetime not null, lastChangedBy varchar(80) not null, lastChangedDate datetime not null, version bigint not null, city varchar(255) not null, person_id integer not null, primary key (id))
 
Hibernate: alter table addresses add index FK_5jlr45lmdkdfggto1dio12j4w (person_id), add constraint FK_5jlr45lmdkdfggto1dio12j4w foreign key (person_id) references Person (id)

Resolving as the original issue was associated with the refresh which has been resolved. The subsequent issue with the update is explained above. One needs to refresh the data model bundle after the update.
